other_notes: Physician Note (2025-09-29 10:15): LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. On September 28th resident demonstrated some physical aggression towards coresident and toward staff according to progress notes. DOS reviewed, not fully complete, and expressions of physical risk on September 28th not captured. She continues on Lorazepam 5 mg po daily and Risperidone was discontinued. Today she appeared calm, ambulatory, and in no distress. Due to some ongoing BPSD with agitation/aggression, Olanzapine will be increased to 7.5 mg po daily. Continue to follow. Abdominal U/S results reviewed. Mass at right liver lobe measuring 5 x 3.5 x 3.6 cm noted, showing an increase size from 2.8 cm. Nodular structure also noted in the region of the head of the pancreas, possibly pancreatic enlargement. Plan to review these results with POA, along with overall discussion of goals of care. Resource nurse to schedule meeting. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED]

Physician Note (2025-09-24 10:07): LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. It is noted that resident had an episode on September 19 described as a "blank stare" for about one minute which occurred after he had been standing and banging his wheelchair. Decreased tone in the limbs was noted, and resident appeared pale at the time. On September 22nd, at approximately 1100 hours resident sustained a fall with no apparent injuries and BP after the incident was noted to be 72/45. He was monitored on head injury routine. Resident does have a known diagnosis of orthostatic hypotension, and receives Midodrine in the morning. Yesterday September 23rd in the evening resident sustained a fall in his room with a scalp laceration. He became agitated when staff attempted to assess VS, and chased staff out of his room, through the corridor and in to the common area. He was not clothed at the time. When given space, resident calmed down and returned to his room. Today, in conversation, resident has a clear memory of these events. He does not remember the circumstances of his fall, but think that he had been sleeping. He describes waking from a deep sleep, finding several Page 1 of 5 Note

Physician Note (2025-09-19 10:26): Note Text : s: POA worried about residents complaints of abdominal pain. Trazodone recently decreased and melatonin started. o: Lethargy noted, Abdomen examined and no tenderness noted. Distention noted. a: ABdominal pain NOS, most likely from ascites P: will monitor, the resident takes diuretics for CHF and unfortunately has a history of renal failure, will monitor for now. Page 1 of 4 Note

No new health concern reported except for mild incontinence dermatitis, related MASD, for which zinc barrier has been started. No other new health concerns. Resident seen to be seated in chair, alert, calm and appears comfortable. Color okay, resps easy and regular. Ongoing CDM. Nursing to follow regarding incontinence MASD. One to one staffing remain in place during the day due to shadowing staff, requiring frequent interaction and redirection etc. Resident was seen to be alert, and ambulatory at times, no distress. Frequently verbalizing and interactive as per her usual. No health concerns reported. Color okay, resps easy and regular. Ongoing CDM. Continue to support BPSD with one to one staffing. Behaviour - Follow up (2025-09-08 17:16): Note Text : The resident was calm this evening . compliant with pills. resident is eating well. no behavior seen during supper time SIGNED]

Physician Note (2025-09-03 10:05): LATE ENTRY Note Text : Assessed on medical rounds. Resident sustained a fall on September lst, monitored on head injury routine with no concerns. He initially reported some discomfort in his hands for which he received prn Tylenol. No subsequent report of pain. Resident has been on pain tracking for quite a while, with no concerns regarding poorly controlled pain noted. Pain scores are generally 0. He does have prn Tylenol available to him. Recent weight and VS stable. Resident appears as per his usual, alert, seated in chair, appeared calm and comfortable. Ongoing falls risk related to Parkinson's, attempts to mobilize independently, unsteady gait, postural hypotension. Ongoing measures for falls prevention. No changes to medical management at this time. Dictated by Dr. Lee Andersen dictated but not read [e-SIGNED] Page 4 of 5 Note

Physician Note (2025-09-04 10:15): Note Text : The resident has been sleeping later in the morning and often misses her morning medications. We will decrease her trazodone at night to 75 mg PO qhs, to see if the morning sedating/fatigue improves. SIGNED]

Physician Note (2025-09-04 10:17): Note Text : Resident has been struggling with current roommate, she is not coping well. The administration will look at her options. She also has dry eyes, and will do a trial of pataday. Her spironolactone is currently backordered, will see if it's actually beneficial, will discontinue for now and monitor. SIGNED]
